model_answer:
The answer should be C: 1 -> 3 -> 2 -> 4 -> 5
The video starts with the speaker talking about the Fluid Mosaic Model, which was proposed by James Watson and Francis Crick in 1959. Then he moves on to describe integral and peripheral proteins and how they are associated with the plasma membrane. He also mentions that transmembrane proteins are glycosylated outside. After this, the view changes to show a phospholipid molecule with its hydrophilic head and hydrophobic tails. This is followed by a slide on the Plasma Membrane & Disease, where various diseases related to the plasma membrane are listed. Finally, there is a blue "Thank you" slide as the speaker concludes his talk and mentions that the next presentation will be about the cytoskeleton.

The answer is C: 1 -> 2 -> 4 -> 3 -> 5.
Firstly, the speaker uses an airport passport control analogy while the “Cell Membrane or Plasma Membrane” slide with bulleted functions stays on screen (1).
Next, the slide changes to “Structure of Cell Membrane” with a colorful bilayer diagram as the speaker details lipids, proteins, and cholesterol (2).
A “Membrane Proteins” slide appears and the speaker states membranes are about 50% protein and 50% lipid by weight, with 5–10% carbohydrates (3).
Finally, a “Fluid Mosaic Model” slide shows three integral protein types while the speaker says they are embedded, folded, and span the membrane via alpha- or beta-helices (4).
The “Plasma Membrane & Disease” slide with a healthy vs cystic fibrosis diagram is displayed as the speaker warns that damaging membrane integrity has severe consequences (5).

Therefore, the chronological order of the sub-events is 1 -> 2 -> 4 -> 3 -> 5.
